titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Ann Imlah Schneider Papers, 1959-2014 and undated RL.11715

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-04-25 11:40:54 -0400.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.unittitle: Ann Imlah Schneider papers
did.abstract: Ann Imlah Schneider's most extensive and recent government service was at the U.S. Department of Education, where she was senior program officer for several of the Education Department's grant programs for international education, under Title VI (of the Higher Education Act). Collection primarily includes publications regarding issues in education, including foreign languages and international and area studies, study abroad, internationalization, business education, and teaching. There are also research files on international education and foreign languages, area studies, Title VI, and governmental regulations; files regarding Schneider's work with Title VI higher education centers for international and area studies; and files related to the Center for Education within the U.S. Department of Education, primarily regarding appropriations.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Ann Imlah Schneider's most extensive and recent government service was at the U.S. Department of Education, where she was senior program officer for several of the Education Department's grant programs for international education, under Title VI (of the Higher Education Act). Her experience also includes work on government-academic relations at the State Department, as well as earlier positions with the senior Fulbright program and with the American Friends Service Committee.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Ann Imlah Schneider Papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2018.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Ann Imlah Schneider Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Accessions described in this collection guide: 2018-0168

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Collection primarily includes publications regarding issues in education, including foreign languages and international and area studies, study abroad, internationalization, business education, and teaching. There are also research files on international education and foreign languages, area studies, Title VI, and governmental regulations; files regarding Schneider's work with Title VI higher education centers for international and area studies; and files related to the Center for Education within the U.S. Department of Education, primarily regarding appropriations.

did.unittitle: Publications

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series includes articles, serials, books, and reports regarding issues in education, with emphasis on higher education, and particularly, foreign languages and international and area studies. Other topics include study abroad, internationalization, business education, and teaching.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Comprises files regarding Schneider's work with Title VI higher education centers for international and area studies. Topics include program planning and evaluation, budgets, and language enrollment.

Program Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Schneider's files related to the Center for Education within the U.S. Department of Education. The files relate primarily to appropriations, with some information on administration, analysis, and allocations. There are also files related to the Department's Committee on the Status of Women (1972-1973), the Presidential Commission on Language and International Studies (1977-1979), and Schneider's conference attendance.
